CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Such a superior device performance is the result of the highest J sc and FF achieved ( Table 3 ) when using 80 °C as a spin - coating temperature compared to those fabricated at 60 or 100 ° C. The decrease in both the J sc and FF could be due to inferior polymer chain packing in the active layer leading to a poor charge transporting network. Besides , the device performance generally varied with the length of alkyl side chains attached onto the polymer backbone. The device efficiency initially increases upon the incorporation of longer alkyl side chains from decyl to tetradecyl reaching a maximum at tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14 and then declines with further alkyl side chain extension. Importantly , such chain Article length - dependent device performance trend is spin - coating temperature independent. The champion PffBB-14 - based device affords the highest PCE of 9.93% with a V oc of 0.92 V , a J sc of 16.77 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 64.36% . The size of the alkyl side chain is known to affect the processability and interchain interactions of a polymer , which would provide a tool to optimize the π-π stacking interactions of a polymer in the solid state. A size - optimized alkyl side chain would provide a good balance between the π-π stacking interactions of the polymer backbone and the alkyl-alkyl side chain interactions resulting in a highly ordered molecular packing for efficient charge transport. Figure 5a shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) spectra of PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs. Strong and broad photo - to - current responses were observed in the range from 330 to 780 nm in all of these PSCs , in which the absorption above 650 nm was attributed to the polymer aggregationinduced absorption broadening. Remarkably , the PffBB-14based device exhibited a much higher photoconversion Article response ranging from 350 to 500 nm than those of other devices , thus affording the highest J sc among all of these devices. As PffBB-n polymers showed similar absorption properties , the high current density of PffBB-14 - based PSC would result from well - ordered polymer : PC71BMnetwork / packing. J sc derived from the EQE spectra were estimated to be 14.12 , 14.92 , 16.29 , and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 - based devices , respectively , which were in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization ( Figure 6 ). Charge Transfer and Recombination. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n - based devices were estimated on hole - only and electron - only devices using the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) model , and the results are summarized in Table 4. Indeed , the highest and well - balanced charge carrier mobility of the PffBB-14:PC71BM blend affords a higher J sc and FF than those of other devices. Charge dissociation probability was characterized by photogenerated current density ( J ph ) vs effective applied voltage ( V eff ) measurements.

Let's think step by step.

1. J sc (Junction Scanning) - It is a material property related to the current density.
2. FF (Fill Factor) - It is a material property related to the efficiency of the device.
3. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency) - It is a material property related to the overall performance of the device.
4. V oc (Open Circuit Voltage) - It is a material property related to the voltage at which the device produces no current.
5. PffBB-n - It is a type of polymer material.
6. PC71BM - It is a type of material used in the device.
7. Alkyl side chains - It is a property of the polymer material.
8. EQE (External quantum efficiency) - It is a material property related to the efficiency of the device in converting photons into electrical current.
9. PSCs (Polymer Solar Cells) - It is a type of device.
10. SCLC (Space Charge Limited Current) - It is a model used to estimate charge carrier mobilities.
11. Charge carrier mobility - It is a material property related to the ability of charge carriers to move through a material.
12. J ph (Photogenerated current density) - It is a material property related to the amount of current generated by photons.
13. V eff (Effective applied voltage) - It is a property related to the voltage applied to the device.
14. Table 3, Table 4 - These are tables mentioned in the text.

So, the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph are: PffBB-n, PC71BM, alkyl side chains, and the materials implied in Table 3 and Table 4.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. PffBB-n
2. PC71BM
3. Table 3 (implies materials in the table)
4. Table 4 (implies materials in the table)

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PffBB-n |
| PC71BM |
| Materials in Table 3 |
| Materials in Table 4 |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Such a superior device performance is the result of the highest J sc and FF achieved ( Table 3 ) when using 80 °C as a spin - coating temperature compared to those fabricated at 60 or 100 ° C. The decrease in both the J sc and FF could be due to inferior polymer chain packing in the active layer leading to a poor charge transporting network. Besides , the device performance generally varied with the length of alkyl side chains attached onto the polymer backbone. The device efficiency initially increases upon the incorporation of longer alkyl side chains from decyl to tetradecyl reaching a maximum at tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14 and then declines with further alkyl side chain extension. Importantly , such chain Article length - dependent device performance trend is spin - coating temperature independent. The champion PffBB-14 - based device affords the highest PCE of 9.93% with a V oc of 0.92 V , a J sc of 16.77 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 64.36% . The size of the alkyl side chain is known to affect the processability and interchain interactions of a polymer , which would provide a tool to optimize the π-π stacking interactions of a polymer in the solid state. A size - optimized alkyl side chain would provide a good balance between the π-π stacking interactions of the polymer backbone and the alkyl-alkyl side chain interactions resulting in a highly ordered molecular packing for efficient charge transport. Figure 5a shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) spectra of PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs. Strong and broad photo - to - current responses were observed in the range from 330 to 780 nm in all of these PSCs , in which the absorption above 650 nm was attributed to the polymer aggregationinduced absorption broadening. Remarkably , the PffBB-14based device exhibited a much higher photoconversion Article response ranging from 350 to 500 nm than those of other devices , thus affording the highest J sc among all of these devices. As PffBB-n polymers showed similar absorption properties , the high current density of PffBB-14 - based PSC would result from well - ordered polymer : PC71BMnetwork / packing. J sc derived from the EQE spectra were estimated to be 14.12 , 14.92 , 16.29 , and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 - based devices , respectively , which were in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization ( Figure 6 ). Charge Transfer and Recombination. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n - based devices were estimated on hole - only and electron - only devices using the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) model , and the results are summarized in Table 4. Indeed , the highest and well - balanced charge carrier mobility of the PffBB-14:PC71BM blend affords a higher J sc and FF than those of other devices. Charge dissociation probability was characterized by photogenerated current density ( J ph ) vs effective applied voltage ( V eff ) measurements.

Let's think step by step.

1. J sc (Junction Scanning) - The current density at the junction of the photovoltaic cell under illumination.
2. FF (Fill Factor) - The maximum reversible power that can be delivered by a solar cell under a given voltage.
3. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency) - The ratio of the electrical power output to the total energy input.
4. V oc (Open Circuit Voltage) - The voltage at which the photovoltaic cell produces no current.
5. Alkyl side chains - Organic side groups attached to the polymer backbone.
6. π-π stacking interactions - Interactions between the aromatic rings of polymers in the solid state.
7. EQE (External quantum efficiency) - The ratio of the number of electrons collected to the number of photons absorbed.
8. PffBB-n - A series of polymers with different alkyl side chain lengths.
9. PC71BM - A fullerene derivative used as an acceptor material in organic solar cells.
10. SCLC (Space Charge Limited Current) - The current flow in a semiconductor under the condition of zero space charge region.
11. J ph (Photogenerated current density) - The current density generated by photogenerated carriers.
12. V eff (Effective applied voltage) - The voltage applied to the photovoltaic cell, taking into account the voltage drop across the device.
13. Table 3, Table 4 - Tables containing data on device performance and charge carrier mobilities, respectively.
14. Figure 5a, Figure 6 - Graphical representations of data.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. J sc (Junction Scanning) - Current density at the junction of the photovoltaic cell under illumination.
2. FF (Fill Factor) - Maximum reversible power delivered by a solar cell under a given voltage.
3. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency) - Ratio of electrical power output to total energy input.
4. V oc (Open Circuit Voltage) - Voltage at which the photovoltaic cell produces no current.
5. Alkyl side chains - Organic side groups attached to the polymer backbone.
6. π-π stacking interactions - Interactions between aromatic rings of polymers in the solid state.
7. J ph (Photogenerated current density) - Current density generated by photogenerated carriers.
8. V eff (Effective applied voltage) - Voltage applied to the photovoltaic cell, taking into account voltage drop across the device.
9. Table 4 - Table containing data on charge carrier mobilities.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| Current density at the junction of the photovoltaic cell under illumination (J sc) |
| Maximum reversible power delivered by a solar cell under a given voltage (FF) |
| Ratio of electrical power output to total energy input (PCE) |
| Voltage at which the photovoltaic cell produces no current (V oc) |
| Organic side groups attached to the polymer backbone (Alkyl side chains) |
| Interactions between aromatic rings of polymers in the solid state (π-π stacking interactions) |
| Current density generated by photogenerated carriers (J ph) |
| Voltage applied to the photovoltaic cell, taking into account voltage drop across the device (V eff) |
| Data on charge carrier mobilities (Table 4) |

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Such a superior device performance is the result of the highest J sc and FF achieved ( Table 3 ) when using 80 °C as a spin - coating temperature compared to those fabricated at 60 or 100 ° C. The decrease in both the J sc and FF could be due to inferior polymer chain packing in the active layer leading to a poor charge transporting network. Besides , the device performance generally varied with the length of alkyl side chains attached onto the polymer backbone. The device efficiency initially increases upon the incorporation of longer alkyl side chains from decyl to tetradecyl reaching a maximum at tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14 and then declines with further alkyl side chain extension. Importantly , such chain Article length - dependent device performance trend is spin - coating temperature independent. The champion PffBB-14 - based device affords the highest PCE of 9.93% with a V oc of 0.92 V , a J sc of 16.77 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 64.36% . The size of the alkyl side chain is known to affect the processability and interchain interactions of a polymer , which would provide a tool to optimize the π-π stacking interactions of a polymer in the solid state. A size - optimized alkyl side chain would provide a good balance between the π-π stacking interactions of the polymer backbone and the alkyl-alkyl side chain interactions resulting in a highly ordered molecular packing for efficient charge transport. Figure 5a shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) spectra of PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs. Strong and broad photo - to - current responses were observed in the range from 330 to 780 nm in all of these PSCs , in which the absorption above 650 nm was attributed to the polymer aggregationinduced absorption broadening. Remarkably , the PffBB-14based device exhibited a much higher photoconversion Article response ranging from 350 to 500 nm than those of other devices , thus affording the highest J sc among all of these devices. As PffBB-n polymers showed similar absorption properties , the high current density of PffBB-14 - based PSC would result from well - ordered polymer : PC71BMnetwork / packing. J sc derived from the EQE spectra were estimated to be 14.12 , 14.92 , 16.29 , and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 - based devices , respectively , which were in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization ( Figure 6 ). Charge Transfer and Recombination. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n - based devices were estimated on hole - only and electron - only devices using the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) model , and the results are summarized in Table 4. Indeed , the highest and well - balanced charge carrier mobility of the PffBB-14:PC71BM blend affords a higher J sc and FF than those of other devices. Charge dissociation probability was characterized by photogenerated current density ( J ph ) vs effective applied voltage ( V eff ) measurements.

Let's think step by step.

1. Jsc (Junction Scanning) and FF (Fill Factor) are material properties related to the device performance. Their values for the champion PffBB-14 based device are:
- Jsc: 16.77 mA cm^-2
- FF: 64.36%

2. The efficiency (PCE) of the champion PffBB-14 based device is also a material property and its value is 9.93%.

3. The Voc (Open Circuit Voltage) of the champion PffBB-14 based device is 0.92 V.

4. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n based devices are material properties. Their values for different devices are given in Table 4, but no specific values are mentioned in the text.

5. The photogenerated current density (Jph) and effective applied voltage (Veff) are material properties related to charge dissociation probability. No specific values are mentioned in the text.

6. The absorption properties of PffBB-n polymers are also material properties. The Jsc values derived from EQE spectra for different devices are:
- PffBB-10: 14.12 mA cm^-2
- PffBB-12: 14.92 mA cm^-2
- PffBB-14: 16.29 mA cm^-2
- PffBB-16: 14.21 mA cm^-2

These values are in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Jsc (Junction Scanning): 16.77 mA cm^-2 (champion PffBB-14 based device)
2. FF (Fill Factor): 64.36% (champion PffBB-14 based device)
3. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency): 9.93% (champion PffBB-14 based device)
4. Voc (Open Circuit Voltage): 0.92 V (champion PffBB-14 based device)
5. Jsc (Junction Scanning) from EQE spectra:
   - PffBB-10: 14.12 mA cm^-2
   - PffBB-12: 14.92 mA cm^-2
   - PffBB-14: 16.29 mA cm^-2
   - PffBB-16: 14.21 mA cm^-2

These are the material properties mentioned in the text.

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

|------------------|-------------------------------|
| Jsc (Junction Scanning) (champion PffBB-14 based device) | 16.77 mA cm^-2 |
| FF (Fill Factor) (champion PffBB-14 based device) | 64.36% |
| PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency) (champion PffBB-14 based device) | 9.93% |
| Voc (Open Circuit Voltage) (champion PffBB-14 based device) | 0.92 V |
| Jsc (Junction Scanning) from EQE spectra (PffBB-10) | 14.12 mA cm^-2 |
| Jsc (Junction Scanning) from EQE spectra (PffBB-12) | 14.92 mA cm^-2 |
| Jsc (Junction Scanning) from EQE spectra (PffBB-14) | 16.29 mA cm^-2 |
| Jsc (Junction Scanning) from EQE spectra (PffBB-16) | 14.21 mA cm^-2 |
